description.text:
I remixed the pulsar spinner to use standard M10 nuts. Everything else is the same as the original.

I printed one and found out that the height of the nuts was not enough for safely accommodating one nut. Redesigned the thing to fix this. Still waiting for the conclusion of this test print.

Printer:

H-I3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

You have to pause the print at the start of the layer that starts to cover the nuts and bearing, so you can insert the hardware.
Since the nuts are a bit taller than the bearing, you actually have to stop printing twice
For my printer, pause command is M25, yours may vary.
Chair by MiguelT [created on 3DTin]
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8mmVOxp8dLR

print_settings.Notes:: We suggest using ABS or PETG for printing, as they are more durable and better withstand high temperatures, but PLA will work as well.

title: E3d v6 Adapter for Flyingbear P902

description.text:
After more than 100 hours of printing time, we share our design of the E3d v6 extruder mount for the Flyingbear P902.
This way the printer has become more precise and reliable, as we have experienced no clogging till now.

You will need to flip the extruder carriage to mount everything, but we think it is worth the effort. Plus, this design won't affect your Z-height (you'll probably gain few mms instead :) )
We designed it using mostly the parts of the stock kit, but still a few more M3 screws and nuts are required.

We designed an adapter for the stock extruder fan as well, because we burnt our 30mm fan and waiting over a month for the replacement. The 40 mm fan works great as well!

Please note that this is a work in progress project, so you may need some minor adjustments mounting it.

UPDATE 22 May: Some minor fixes to the design, and added two holes to attach the cooling fan to the extruder in a more stable way.
ADDED an .iges file to let you mod everything. Please mark anyhing you make as a remix, so we can download it as well! Thank you.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

We suggest using ABS or PETG for printing, as they are more durable and better withstand high temperatures, but PLA will work as well.

Harry Potter Drink Coasters! I've also included 3 vertical stands. One for 3.5mm material and one for 7.1mm material, which happen to be the most common thicknesses of wood I buy. If you're using another thickness just pick the closes one to yours and modify it. Enlarge or shrink the holes and adjust the length of the tabs on the support pieces. Also be careful that the coasters will fit in the slots made for them. The slots should accommodate a coaster of the given thickness plus an additional 1.5mm cork backer if you choose to use them.

This was made in Corel Draw X7 and I've also included a PDF.

The coasters in the picture are 1/4" hickory cut and engraved with a 45w CO2 laser.

comments.text: I have access to a Thunder laser and Illustrator, so am not able to use the .cdr   When I import the .pdf to RDWorks8, the border shows up as solid black and wants to raster the whole edge (where the HP is).  I tried using illustrator to save as .ai, but that didn't seem to work either. I'm fairly new to illustrator and laser cutting in general and am not sure why that might be happening. Any ideas why?
comments.author: LadySandry

comments.text: Depends on how the PDF was created. Does it open up in Adobe Reader and look fine in the screen? What I do when I run into PDFs that open up funny in Corel or similar program, I download and install CutePDF Writer. It acts as a virtual printer to create PDFs. I open the PDF in question in Adobe Reader or Foxit Reader and print it to CutePDF to recreate the PDF again. It usually works. It must simplify the artwork somehow but keeps it in layers and vectorized. Usually it opens correctly afterwards. I do the same thing with SVG files that open up funny as well. I print from Internet Explorer to CutePDF Writer as a PDF and the file is perfect.
comments.author: LadySandry

comments.text: Sorry, I use CorelDraw with both CorelLaser and RDWorks8. With CorelLaser printing to my K40 is pretty simple. With RDWorks on my bigger laser, I have to set the layers to different colors before I export to RDWorks so I have separate layers and I can set the modes. I will upload a new file with different color layers and hopefully this will help you. I use black to cut and red for scan in RDWorks. Check back in a little bit and I should be done with the modification and upload.
comments.author: LadySandry

comments.text: I see the new file has been uploaded. Thanks you so much for being so helpful :)

The difficult thing is going between inkscape at home and illustrator at my local makerspace when I'm pretty new at both programs.  :)   Thanks for the help, these coasters are too cool

I've made a lot of these for gifts and the Harry Potter fans really love them.

comments.text: How did you get the HP in the circle all the way around. Is that a coreldraw function?
comments.author: Baumer

comments.text: Yes. After creating the circle for the cut, I placed the HP logo at the top. Then I moved the center point of the HP to match the circle. You do that by clicking the object so that it shows the rotate symbols and then dragging the center down until it snaps to the center of the circle. This makes the copies you're about to create place themselves relative to the circle.

title: Funko POP! Fallout 4 Power Armor Station

description.text: I designed this custom Fallout 4 power armor station as an accessory for the Funko POP! Fallout characters, but I'm sure there are other cool uses for it. I tried to make it as printer friendly as I could, and mine was actually printed without any supports, although I would recommend using some yourself. Mine is painted with spay paint and acrylics and I used fine sand for the dirt piles.

Printer:

Aurora Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print 1 powerstationbtm and 1 powerstationtop and glue together.
I did not use supports when printing this and it turned out very well, but depending on your printer you may get different results. The hydraulic cylinders were a little fragile, and may print better with supports, but they aren't strictly necessary. I would also recommend supports for powerstationbtm because of the junction box, which is floating just above the bed. I included the full model stl file for anyone that wants to try to print the whole thing at once.

remixed_from.author: jamesarm97
remixed_from.title: Replicator Y Axis Rod pillow block

title: Replicator/FF Y-Shaft Pillow Block, with drill guide

description.text:
The Replicator and FlashForge Creator need additional support on the 5mm Y-axis shafts, so a popular modification has been to add additional bearings mounted in pillow blocks.  However an item of discussion on the forums has been the correct standoff distance of the bearing from the rear or front panels.  Apparently it can vary somewhat.  
This version of a pillow block includes the OpenSCAD code, with a parametric setting to adjust the standoff distance to suit your application.  
Additionally, I hate fiddling with loose nuts, so this incorporates nut holders which should simplify assembly.  A 'washer plate' is also included to go under the exterior bolt heads.  
EDIT 1/16/15:  To my shame, almost a year later and I've not yet installed these on my own Replicator.  And the reason for that is, that I've been sure I'd goof up drilling the mounting holes, and wind up with something that would bind, rather than support, the shafts.  OCD prevents just drilling outsize holes.  So, I've finally gotten around to making a drill guide.  With this addition, you can be confident that you can get all of the pillow blocks identically and accurately (enough) placed.  
EDIT 3/22/15:  Finally, I have installed these myself on my Replicator, using the drill guide.  The fit was actually perfect with no binding detectable.

Using the new drill guide: See the photos. While presumably all Replicator and FF frames are cut or derived from the same basic CAD files. It would be a good idea to check the shaft locations. So first you place the guide on the side of the Replicator in a corner as shown. You should be able to 'bullseye' the shaft location in the larger guide hole. Make sure the guide is flat against the side, the top edge is flat against the top edge of the side, and slide the guide forward until the 'arm' just touches the inside face of the front. If the shaft is centered in the hole, then the center of the shaft is 28mm from the top edge, and 13mm from the inner face of the front. If it's not 28mm from the top, you can change the 'shaftfromtop' parameter in the OpenSCAD code to match what you've got, and print another guide. If it's not 13mm from the front, you'd need to shim the pillow block, or adjust the height in the pillow block code. Then, you just hold the guide in place at the left and right edges of the front and back panels, as shown, where it will mark the location for each drill hole. The holes will match the span of the pillow block and be spaced correctly from the top edge. Both holes will be 45mm from the side, which should just clear the y-rod holders. (The 'arm' serves no further purpose in hole positioning.) You can just drill through the guide and panel, or mark the holes for later drilling. A transfer punch is easily the best way to mark the holes. (A set of transfer punches is really inexpensive and you'll be surprised at how much you use them.) Since the pillow block standoff distance is adjustable, this would actually be a good application for the Customizer. However, I dread seeing a bunch of "My Pillow Block" spam things, so I refuse to use it on principle. The only other thing to note is that to shove the nuts into the slots, it's best to hold them with some needle-nose pliers, and shove them in such that one of the 'points' of the nuts goes in first - that's the only way they'll fit. Otherwise, install just like either of the two ancestor things. I printed at 0.2mm with 20% fill.

comments.text: These are actually unnecessary. While there is some minor amount of vibration caused by the bar not being secured, it doesn't affect The motion of the Y-Axis. It is something that we old timers would call, "snake oil". So, if you've got a CTC 3D printer, you can be confident that you will get good prints without this "upgrade". Now, if you want to do it anyway, have at it. However, unless you have before and after prints of the exact same part that show a difference, rest assured that there won't be any difference. It will perhaps set your mind at ease having them there, but it's really much ado about nothing. Also, the Z-Axis screw does move about somewhat. This also doesn't really matter, as the print quality is governed by the two guide rods on either side of the Z-Axis screw. If you want more accuracy in the X and Y axes, you'd be better advised to make those guide rods more secure, than to worry about the screw moving. In fact, I would say that making that modification should be the single most important upgrade you can make to these printers. Putting pillow block bearing on those two rods would do a LOT more to ensure quality prints.

comments.text:
Very nice design! Thanks! I modified it slightly so I can insert or remove the pillow block without removing the bearing from the shaft, so it's easy to experiment with the dimensions of the block. Mainly I added a 5mm slot in the base, and changed the way the bearing is retained so it's easy to get it in or out by minor flexing of the block. I clicked "Remix" here, which I thought would link to it, but don't see that as yet--my variant is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:341284http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
You just have to slide the shaft part way out, slip some bearings onto it, and slide it back, then align and tighten the pulleys again. Once that's done, trying variants of the pillow block is very quick. (Your nut traps are a big help!)

title: Full Size Minion Goggles for Halloween Costumes

description.text: These are goggles used to make my Minion Halloween Costume. printed in three parts and glued together. I included an IGS file for those that want to take these and use them for their own costume. I worked hard on the 3D model to get proportions and details correct. These are designed to fit on a 12" diameter helmet/head. I used foam and wood to make the head for my costume. To see my entire Halloween costume construction process for the lovable Minions from Despicable me, check out my Blog: http://www.projectsbyzac.com/1048/halloween-costumes/how-to-make-a-minion-halloween-costume-part-1

These minion goggles are quite large as they are designed to fit onto a minion head of 12" in Diameter but you should be able to slice the files if your printer is not capable of printing an object of this size.  I printed the three parts and then glued with Acetone/dissolved ABS filament.   A bit of sanding and painting.  I wish I had an acetone vapor bath at the time I made these.  Painting really showed the layers on the parts.

2pdr Portee on CMP 30wt truck. I've been waiting so long to be able to print these, as the Battlefront model just didn't do it for me (especially at that price tag).

Thanks to marcusmole for sourcing the 2pdr model, which I had to drastically simplify for printing.
CMP truck is by m_berman, with edits by myself.

Printing and assembly should be pretty straight forward. Folded carriage is mounted to the pin on the truck bed, and then the storage/bench glued at the rear if desired. Turret is left freestanding to rotate.
Included a deployed carriage if you want to run non-portee,

As Monoprice refuses to send me an RMA for my printer until they have more in stock, I am still without the ability to test print. My backlog is starting to grow...

Until then, let me know if this works, and what needs to be tweaked/improved.

Expect this to be updated in the coming weeks.

description.text:
Go Empire

This is a Death Star inspired bookend.


CAD Files

This Death Star bookend was created as two parts and merged into one: the bookend, and the half of the Death Star. The file for the Death Star was created/remixed from Smashley's Tree Topper Death Star. I merged his two top and bottom halves and then cut it in half again. Once I had this vertically cut half of the Death Star I merged it with a bookend. I have provided files for the final product, the death star half, and the bookend.


Electronics

After the death star bookend was printed I created a small electronics system that would fit in the hollowed out death star and make the light effect for the death star that is shown in This Video (You might have to right click and open the link in a new tab for the link to work). I included a GIF of the video with the photos above, but Thingiverse will only display an the thumbnail of the gif and not the whole gif.

To create this I used an RG LED with a 150Ohm resistor per LED anode lead (one resistor before the red prong and one resistor before the green prong). I also used a 22kOhm resistor with the button, but it is covered in heat shrink in the pictures. I connected these all to an Arduino Nano. The Arduino files can be found Here. If you want more information, like a wiring diagram, check out This Post that has additional information and instructions.

The death star does not print with the hole for the LED. That way, if you don't want to use the electronics, you don't have to deal with a hole in the death star.


Thanks!

Special thanks to Smashley for sharing his Death Star file!

Please feel free to tweak and modify the files I've provided. If you have any questions, post them in the comments and I will do my best to answer them. If you print or make one of these, please share it with the "I Made One" feature. I'd love to see them! Thanks and Enjoy!


Edit:

Smashley brought it to my attention that the original edit was from kystopz89's Death Star. Thanks kystopz89 for sharing too!

title: Tronxy X3 Extruder Cooling Fan Cover

description.text:
Now I realize that there are MANY versions of an Extruder Cooling cover for the Tronxy X3 but I am a bit of a minimalist so I created this. This only replaces the stock metal cover that comes with the X3, it does not have a part cooling, leveling collar or end stop adapter. I needed this because the stock adaptor also cooled the extruder heater which basically means the X3 was fighting with itself when heating up the extruder. I didn't notice it with the Melzi controller, but the stock Repetier EEPROM code I used when setting up my Ramps controller noticed it and kept on decoupling the heaters. They probably disabled that feature with their version of Repetier EEPROM, stupid really.

The advantage of this cover is all the air is forced to flow around the heat sink fins. Since there is space behind the heat sink, because of the standoff screws, there is plenty of space for the air to flow. I used a thermistor to measure the heat of the sink when the extruder was at very high temperatures and it registered a cool 32 °C, just a bit higher than room temperature.

I do plan on adding some upgrades to this design for part cooling, leveling collar or end stop adapter but they will be as bolt on parts so you won't need to reprint and waste material.

with my hatred of overhangs, I designed this with very gentle ones, you should be ok in that respect.

As usual, I would love to hear from everyone on suggestions. I seem to love designing things so let me hear them.

Printer:

Tronxy X3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Here are some of the settings I used in slic3r:

  • Layer height: .2mm
  • First: .28mm
  • Perimeters: 4
  • Top / Bottom: 3
  • Infill: 15% Rect

Using these speeds:

  • Perimeters: 60mm
  • Ext Per: 35mm
  • Infill: 60mm
  • S Infill: 80%
  • Travel: 130mm
  • First Layer 25mm

I printed this in roughly 1 hour.

The construction sequence is as follows:

  • Remove the original cover.
  • Remove the fan from the cover.
  • Pop the nuts out from the fan, the easiest way I found to do this is to screw in a long bolt into the nut and pry it out.
  • Detach the extruder body, the two bolts holding the heatsink to the Y trolly.
  • This step is optional: The distance from the bottom of the heatsink to the extruder head was a bit close for my liking. I suggest extending it to where the gap is 6 to 7 millimeters.
  • Slip the cover we made over the extruder heat sink. NOTE: There could be a bit of play here what we want is for it to be tight. What I did to fix this is took a piece of the black coil cover from the wires and wedge it between the sink and the cover. This worked quite well because it's somewhat flexible and the perfect thickness.
  • Now you are going to bolt the extruder back on the trolly with the cover. Take the two bolts and remove the washer but not the biting washer. Then through the front of the cover push the screws through the holes of the heat sink and bolt it back onto the trolly. It's a bit dodgy at this point, I had trouble holding on to the screws and had to use some pliers to push them through and I might need to adjust the model around hear. I will probably fix this in a later version, but it should work with some tinkering.
  • Now bolt the fan to the front of the cover and you are done.

description.text: This is a phone case that has working gears on it.

My daughter wanted to do a 3D printed Valentine's Day for her classmates this year. We chose this simple necklace that holds a Hershey's Kiss. They can enjoy a single kiss or keep it reserve for a chocolate emergency. I printed these on a Rep2 at Standard (Layer .20mm), the top and bottom snapped together well. Depending on the print seam, connecting them could be a touch finicky. To take it apart, its best to squeeze the top piece at its fattest point just above the bottom piece. I have included bottoms with a smiley, a first aid cross, an "emergency" exclamation mark, and plain. Just add your own string through the holes at the top to make for a quick and easy little gift. title: Begleri Fidget for M4/M8 hex nuts

description.text:
This is a printable model of the classic begleri greek toy. There are some designs out there but I wanted to use the hex nuts available locally so I designed these.

Just print it, insert M4 or M8 hex nuts, use shoelaces/parachord to keep it tight in both sides and in the two beads and you are done. Google for 'begleri' and see some videos, you won't regret. This is a GREAT toy if you like fidgets. As you just need two of this little beads, 6 M4 nuts (or more depending on the weight you want) and an old shoelace this is really CHEAP, quick and easy to make. Why not give it a chance? Be warned: playing with this is very addictive and funny!!

No support required for print, bridging works Ok for the small gap.
Enjoy!

UPDATE (18-MAY-2017): Redesigned M8 model to be slightly smaller, normally just a M8 hex nut is enough, otherwise you can hurt your hands easily if you're not an expert (ouch!).

title: Key chain camera mount for Blade Helicopter B450

description.text: If you are a heli freak like me, read this: Some time ago I have ordered a wide angle key chain camera and have attached it with tape to the canope at the front of my Blade 450 helicopter. After some flights the idea came up to improve the camera installation and adjust the angle of view without tape-technology. As a result I have designed a 2-axis variable camera mount printed on a 3D printer. The angle of view can be adjusted before each flight manually so no changes in-flight. This camera is a nice first and cheap step to get into aerial photography before heading to more expensive and professional systems. The costs for the 3D printed parts where about 18 Euro and 30 Euro for the key cam. To see examples of view angles click the link http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FmuT8nY4gHQ&feature=youtu.be

Step 1 Printing 3D
Never printed 3D? Now it's time! You don't own a 3D printer? No problem: go to http://www.3dhubs.com/ , register and select a 3D printer in your neighborhood. Pay online and grab it later. Works fantastic. Print your parts with ABS in medium resolution, thickness 0,2mm, low speed. Check at the 3D printers Hub what color they offer for printing.
My camera mount parts where printed at Oliver's Hub in Zurich (Switzerland) on a Up-Mini 3D printer. To achieve best results, the orientation of how the parts shall be printed is attached. Step 2 Surface treat your parts
Smooth the surface of the parts with an acetone steam bath. Instruction is attached as PDF file. After treatment, drill the holes according to the screw DIN M3 diameter. Step 3 Assembly and installation
Assemble the parts according to the attached pictures. The part which will be attached to the helicopter canope needs to be reworked with a cutter. Parts used:
-2ea screws M3x12mm
-3ea self-locking M3 nuts
-2ea washer for M3
-1ea screw M3x8mm
-hot glue to fill in the gaps between the helicopter canope and the camera mount. I know it's a dirty technique but ... because hot glue is not the best process/mean to attach things to a vibrating vehicle like a helicopter, I have secured the cam mount with an extra screw to the canope of the heli. See pictures.
-wide angle key camera (DV20 808 # 20 HD video recorder for 30Ã¢ÂÂ¬ at eBay from a Hongkong based seller)
-thick, flexible double tape to attach the cam to the bracket Step 4 Testing and lift-off
PRE-FLIGHT CHECK: Check if the modification has a negative impact on your heli model (e.g. too long screws chafing on the heli batterie or cables etc.)
PRECAUTION: nothing special. The heli weight is about 700grams and the camera mount add about 57grams including camera. Although the installation causes an imbalance for the helicopter (the mass is installed outside the center of gravity of the heli), only little control trimming was required on my heli. Evaluate your heli configuration.
BEST PRACTICE : check the film quality in hover position. If the film is wiggly, change the attachment of the key cam in the bracket. tie it harder or less. As said, this is a cheap but enjoyable thing so do not expect perfect movies. Enjoy! Step 5 Film read out
On the micro SD card of the key cam the film sequences are registered. To read them out, just connect the cam with the computer and the SD card will be listed as drive. My films I have cut and edited with Magix Movie Software. See an example on youtube: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WkS0qComzhA

title: Supermarine 371-II Airfoil Micro Drone Propeller (29.13g thrust @ 3V)

description.text:
The micro drone propeller was designed after the Supermarine 371-II airfoil. All testing was done on the Drone Propeller Thrust Testing Jig You can inspect the results below.

I printed this part with a slow setting, with the help of a 0.2 extruder nozzle at 0.04 layer height. I cleaned the final part with a Precision Knife

After this, it was sanded with a small piece of 400 grit sandpaper.

Here are the thrust measurements for the 4 picked voltage values (these can also be viewed in the image files):

  • 1.5V => 10.11 grams
  • 2V => 13.74 grams
  • 2.5V => 24.63 grams
  • 3V => 29.13 grams

The files you can download consist of all shots taken during the test, with 6 text files that have all the airfoil coordinates used in the build, the printable STL files and the SLDPRT files. If you want to tinker with this propeller, you need to get a 8520 coreless motor.

Use the SLDPRT files, just in case you desire to make your own changes to the propeller.

Note: Airfoil plotted by using the matplotlib library for python.

author: emanuelbucsa

title: TsAGI R-3a Airfoil Micro Drone Propeller (32.40g thrust @3V)

description.text:
I created the micro drone propeller using the TsAGI R-3a airfoil coordinates. Testing was performed on the Micro Drone Propeller Thrust Testing Jig All results can be checked below.

It was printed slowly, with the help of a 0.2 nozzle at 0.04mm height per layer. The final part was cleaned with a Precision Knife

After this, I got to finishing the part with a small piece of 400 grit sandpaper.

These are the measurements for some voltage presets (you can also view these in the images):

  • 1.5V => 7.45 grams
  • 2V => 14.13 grams
  • 2.5V => 25.04 grams
  • 3V => 32.4 grams

The included files consist of all shots taken during the test, with 6 text files that have all the airfoil coordinates used in the build, the printable STL files and the SLDPRT files. If you'd like to tinker with the propeller, you should grab a bunch of 8520 coreless motors.

You can use the SLDPRT extension files, just in case you desire to make your own changes to the propeller.

Note: Airfoil plotted with the matplotlib library in python.

title: LED Light Strip Dimmer Connections Housing and Conduit

description.text:
This is an add-on to a popular dimmer that is used to dim LED strips lights. In my case, the dimmer is mounted on the underside of a cabinet over a work surface. The power supply is located out of view on the topside of the cabinet. I wanted this enclosure for the wire connections to prevent accidentally bumping the wires when I blindly reach for the dimmer knob.

I added a rigid spiral conduit to run the cables back to the rear underside of the cabinet. I could have alternately used common wire clamps nailed to the cabinet, but I think that this will look more interesting. If I want to add more cabling later, I can use the spiral opening to spin in the new cable.

The length of the conduit is 27cm. The outer diameter is 2cm.

description.text:
This is a hanger hook for a telephone receiver, used to hold it on the side of flat surface. I have a VOIP phone, and purchased a corded receiver to use when talking, both to allow others to see when I'm on the phone, and to keep a dedicated sound device for the phone.

There are holes in the back for inserting common 1/4" x 1/16" magnets if that's the desired method of hold, though double-back tape works as well.

Note there is a small nub printed on one side. This is for holding the coil cord when not in use. It is designed to allow the coil to freely come off when the receiver is lifted for use.

Designed in OpenSCAD, files attached if you'd like to re-mix.

description.text:
Update 27.05.2017: Uploaded corrected version of Backplate with Belt holder in right direction (thanks to RehabMD). Also uploaded the small part of the Belt Tensioner separatly in Case print fails.

Update 20.05.2017: added Sensor Mount for 18mm inductive/capacitive Sensor and BLTouch (3DTouch) Sensor. Didn´t test the Mounts yet but should fit.

I´ve created a backplate for TNS´s great Bowden Extruder Carriage as I want my Carriage as liteweight as possible. It includes a x-belt holder and tightener, Sensor Holders as well as bearing blocks which fit to linear ball bearings as well as Igus bearings but might need a bit of glue or locktide to keep the bearings in place. I didnt want to add screws as it would be additional weight and with glue works for me now since a while.

I might add different Sensor holders soon but for the moment you can also design it yourself.

You can find TNS´s Bowden Carriage here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2099577
Also Thanks to Phil_Maddox as I took the Design for the Bearing Blocks from him: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1404861

I also uploaded the Sketchup File so feel free to improve and share my design.

title: Brackets for 20mm x 20mm Aluminium Profile
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
16 Brackets for 20mm x 20mm Aluminium Profile
M5- 10mm or 12mm Socket Head Bolts
Walls are 6mm Thick- -- Brackets are in there Printing Position

These are Tough Brackets designed for 3d printing so the weakness of the FFF process has been taking into consideration when designing them --

The great thing about using them is you can get a Precision Dimension to your frame without the need for Precision cuts on the Aluminium Profile,,, a 3mm error can easily be compensated for—

Use a pieces of wood/aluminium cut to the internal size as a measuring/pressure stick when bolting together ,,,you will get far better dimension accuracy then trying to use a Tape Measure or a Ruler,,,just cut the internal measuring sticks 4cm shorter than the actual size you need
to compensate for the thickness of 2 aluminium Beams

There are small changes in each of the brackets Design and the amount of Bolt Holes they have to allow for different circumstances----

There will be a few more that will added to this lot in a couple of weeks-
3 piece Corners
Swivel Style Brackets
Adjustable Angle Type

This file will be deleted and Replace with the -" V2 Version" when there tested and ready

I modified gavincol78's version of this to accept 2040 extrusion. I just added the extra 20mm vertically. This is not tested so if you end up printing it please leave comments on how it went. I also added a .4mm layer at the bottom of the upper screw holes so bridging the gap would be a bit easier.

Protomaker, I upgraded because I wanted better performance and the ability to print with ninja flex and filaflex without issue (Success!)

Many of these parts have gone through many different tests and revisions, these are the final versions I've used as of May 17, 2017.

Made my own design based on my collection of 2mmx10mm pastic screws and for some reason I only had 5 mm 3m screws for the stepper motors. Designed a plug to hold the hot end in place, I wanted to remove and replace the hot end without taking off the extruder hotend.

Assembly is pretty straight forward, but instructions are always good.
As any reprap mendel, you'll need threaded rods, lead screw with flanged nut, smooth rods, nuts, bolts, tie wraps, motors, 5/8mm couplers, endstops 608 bearings, linear bearings, wires, arduino and ramps and stuff or equivalent, hot end and fans.

*Extruder block and extruder block 2 are the same, just flipped 90 degress. Same goes for the extruder plug. These are for two different size hot end hear sink fittings i have.

-X and Y end stops, using the mech endstop v1.2, i've desoldered the button and screwed it into place and soldered extension wires to the board. The Y axis endstop I sanded down to fit under the build plate with clearance. X axis motor mount has mounting holes for the pbcb and button.

Every bolt needs a washer. Including the z axis mount against the top vertex (should be washer-bolt-washer in order to align with the z bracket at the bottom and x axis mounts.

I could go into more detail, but it kindof builds itself once you have all the pieces printed. Let me know if you feel otherwise.

Extruder needs a PTFE 4mm OD tube chopped to fit snugly between the hobbed bolt and bearing for the filaflex and ninjaflex to travel straight and not get krinkled

**X Axis motor mount has very tight holes, cut out the support and use a vice to squish in the lead screw bolt. Also, ream out the holes for the smooth rods and gently hammer them in. The X axis Idler mount has looser holes so that one side can be adjusted easier.

The original holes are threaded way too fine to be able to print properly, so the holes here are a bit small on purpose to give the screws some material to grip onto. Might need to widen them a tiny bit after you print.

I recommend printing at 100% infill; no supports needed if you print upside-down. The STL is set up to print this way.

A Spinner inspired by the Bask Country symbol: the lauburu.

Insert 2 608Z and spin!

I made this model in Tinkercad, and then cut it into two pieces and added a threaded connector to the two pieces.  
I will be printing this on a Printrbot Simple, so I only had a small build area so I wanted a way to make a larger rocket.  
Finally got a working model to print, took me four different tries to fix the bottoms of the side rocket fin things.  They kept snapping off either mid print, or after it was printed.  Also, the screw thread idea had to be scrapped because my printer is not perfectly calibrated.  I opted for trying the pin system from a user on thingiverse.  Mixed results on the pin connector, but it got it together which is all I wanted.  
Phew.  Many trials and errors, but I do like the final model.

title: Extruded Lid for CNC 1590A or A+

description.text:
Extruded lid for CNC 1590A+, to fit a LiPo or just some extra clearance for 2S 18650 configurations. If you want this to fit a Hammond 1590A, then scale in slicer settings- 93.0mm X 38.5mm

This lid will provide an 8.50mm extruded clearance for battery pack/18650's. Works great on Hammond 1590A boxes using these MosMax Electronics battery sleds.. Owner of MosMax, David, says they won't work in hammond 1590A boxes, and normally they won't, but I get them to work using these lids.

Or you can 3D print a battery sled for 1590A boxes.

I personally use 1/2" grub screws on the enclosure and leave them protruding out about 1/4" and I don't even need magnets to keep these lids firmly attached. The grub screws will catch just right and hold the lid firmly in place. Magnets will always make a stronger hold though.

More box mod parts here- http://www.thingiverse.com/Madyn3D-CNC_LLC/designs/page:1

Please email [email protected] for custom lids and designs. Any sized enclosures, any design possible.

author: rasor

title: iPhone 7 and 7Plus Cases - Ultra Thin Rigid

description.text:
This case is very thin, with smooth contours. I was careful to make sure that the openings for the phone buttons and camera were precisely located. The vertical and horizontal curve profiles are very close to apple specs.

I tried other designs from various sites, and was disappointed by poor fit, hole mis-alignment, and unnecessarily sharp edges.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

150 um, or 200um

Infill:

N/A

Notes:

I have built these models with PLA and with PETG. I recommend using 0.2 mm resolution for printing with PETG (for better bridging at the button holes).

Important Note on scaling:
These models are designed to precisely match the iPhone exteriors. Due to normal tolerances in printing, you should consider scaling up the model in your slicer, depending on the type of material you are using.

If using a flexible material, no scaling (100%) is recommended.

For PLA, or PETG, use this scaling:
X -- 100.50% (width, 80.81mm for the 7+, and 69.26mm for the 7)
Y -- 100.30% (length, 160.73mm for the 7+, and 140.11mm for the 7)
Z -- 104.00% (thickness, 8.09mm for the 7+, and 7.87mm for the 7)

I use Blender for modeling.

I leveraged the contours from an iPhone 6 silicon case designed by https://grabcad.com/stoian-1 the model: https://grabcad.com/library/iphone-6-case-1

Currently, the chambers are 11.5 mm in diameter, and the rods are 10 mm.  This results in a fair amount of slop, as well as some extra noise due to the rods banging around in their chambers as they move, but the mechanism spins very freely.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: Hobson's Coupler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A Hobson's Coupler (or Hobson's Joint) is a mechanism that diverts rotational power around a corner. Unlike a universal joint, it can function at an angle of 90 degrees and is a true constant velocity joint, but the angle is fixed at construction..

I designed these parts so I'd have a simple model to play around with. Three or more angled rods (there are four in this design) connect a pair of rotating cylinders (which each resembles the cylinder in a revolver). Each arm of a rod is free to slide and rotate within its "chamber" in the cylinder. The rods force the cylinders to rotate in sync with one another. As a rod moves closer to the point where the cylinders are nearest, both arms of the rod slide into their respective chambers. As the rod moves further away, the arms slide back out.

The mechanism is used purely as a coupler in applications like the 90 degree Gearless Angle Drive (a ratchet/socket driver attachment by Cal-Van Tools), and in certain shaft-driven bicycle designs. It can also function as an engine in its own right (with the rods acting as the engine's pistons), such as in steam or compressed-air powered Elbow Engines, or in the 1970s Bricklin-Turner Rotary Vee concept engine (and similar designs ). It is also the basis for the fictional V-Engine used in the mecha setting Heavy Gear.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

You will need to print four rods (a total of eight half rods), two cylinders, one mounting bracket -- and optionally, one stand and one or more gluing jigs.

Use whatever rigid plastic you prefer. My suggestion for aesthetics would be to print the cylinders and the stand with the same color filament (call it A). Then print the mounting bracket in a contrasting filament (call it B), and print three of the rods with either A or B. Finally, the last rod would either be printed in whichever filament you didn't use for the other three rods, or with a third filament C. For example, A is black, B is white, and C is bright red. The ideal goal is mostly just to make one rod stand out from the other three so it can be observed/talked about more easily; the rest is just preference.

I purposely made the tolerance around the rods pretty loose to ensure that the mechanism wouldn't bind if the parts were printed out of square. Currently, the chambers are 11.5 mm in diameter, and the rods are 10 mm. This results in a fair amount of slop, as well as some extra noise due to the rods banging around in their chambers as they move, but the mechanism spins very freely.

The only non-printed items I used for this model were a pair of 608 skate bearings, a little epoxy or superglue to assemble the halves of each rod, and something for light sanding on the rods (to smooth off raised imperfections, like the "flashing lines" caused by the extra extrusion on the first layer). Nail file, sanding block, whatever. You can probably get away without or substitute for any or all of these extra things (and the mounting bracket) if you are feeling creative/lazy.

A jig is included in the printable files. This part is meant to help align the halves of each rod as they are glued together. Put the lower half of the rod into the jig, put on a little glue on the top surface, then put on the other half of the rod. Make sure they are aligned as well as possible, and then set some weight on top until it dries.

Each rod also has a little triangle on one end. It doesn't strictly matter if both halves of this triangle are on the same end; it's mostly there just in case you want to make sure you aren't putting two of the same half together.

The skate bearings mount on the posts on the end of each cylinder, and in the recess in the mounting bracket. Friction is the only thing holding the these parts together, which might or might not be enough for your parts as printed. Gluing the bearings (carefully) to their respective parts may be needed. Only use adhesive between the inner rim of the bearing and its post, and between the outer rim of the bearing and the outer wall of the mounting bracket.

If the assembly is laid flat on a table, the mounting bracket is designed to be hold the cylinders far enough off of the surface that they can turn freely. However, it needs a little weight on the corner diagonal from the four rods, in order to keep the bracket level to the table.

The optional stand clamps onto the middle of the mounting bracket to display the mechanism in the "diamond" orientation shown in the cover photo. Turned that way, gravity prevents the cylinders from sliding off the bearings on their own.
